title: Frequency and period - block and sphere mass ratio

content.question: A spring is hung vertically with its top end fixed in place. A block is attached to the bottom end of the spring, displaced downward from its equilibrium position, and released from rest. As the block oscillates, a student measures the distance <math alttext="delta y sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> between the block’s minimum and maximum positions, and the time <math alttext="delta t sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> it takes the block to complete ten oscillations. The procedure is then repeated with a sphere attached to the bottom of the same spring, with the student measuring the distance <math alttext="delta y sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> between the sphere’s minimum and maximum positions, and the time <math alttext="delta t sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> it takes the sphere to complete ten oscillations. In order to determine the ratio of the masses of the block and the sphere, which measurements can be used or what quantity is still needed?

choices.label: The ratio can be determined from <math alttext="delta y sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta y sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> only.

The ratio can be determined from <math alttext="delta t sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta t sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> only.

<math alttext="delta y sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta y sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta t sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="delta t sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> are all needed and can be used to determine the ratio.
The spring constant must still be determined in order to determine the ratio.

content.answer: The ratio can be determined from <math alttext="delta t sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta t sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> only.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
